title: Cauchy distribution
text:
The Cauchy distribution, named after <a href="Augustin%20Cauchy">Augustin Cauchy</a>, is a <a href="continuous%20probability%20distribution">continuous probability distribution</a>. It is also known, especially among <a href="physicist">physicist</a>s, as the Lorentz distribution (after <a href="Hendrik%20Lorentz">Hendrik Lorentz</a>), Cauchy–Lorentz distribution, Lorentz(ian) function, or Breit–Wigner distribution. The Cauchy distribution formula_1 is the distribution of the -intercept of a ray issuing from formula_2 with a uniformly distributed angle. It is also the distribution of the <a href="Ratio%20distribution">ratio of two</a> independent <a href="Normal%20Distribution">normally distributed</a> random variables with mean zero.
The Cauchy distribution is often used in statistics as the canonical example of a "<a href="pathological%20%28mathematics%29">pathological</a>" distribution since both its <a href="expected%20value">expected value</a> and its <a href="variance">variance</a> are undefined (but see below). The Cauchy distribution does not have finite <a href="moment%20%28mathematics%29">moment</a>s of order greater than or equal to one; only fractional absolute moments exist. The Cauchy distribution has no <a href="moment%20generating%20function">moment generating function</a>.
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, it is closely related to the <a href="Poisson%20kernel">Poisson kernel</a>, which is the <a href="fundamental%20solution">fundamental solution</a> for the <a href="Laplace%20equation">Laplace equation</a> in the <a href="upper%20half-plane">upper half-plane</a>.
It is one of the few distributions that is <a href="stable%20distribution">stable</a> and has a probability density function that can be expressed analytically, the others being the <a href="normal%20distribution">normal distribution</a> and the <a href="L%C3%A9vy%20distribution">Lévy distribution</a>.
History.
Functions with the form of the density function of the Cauchy distribution were studied by mathematicians in the 17th century, but in a different context and under the title of the <a href="witch%20of%20Agnesi">witch of Agnesi</a>. Despite its name, the first explicit analysis of the properties of the Cauchy distribution was published by the French mathematician <a href="Sim%C3%A9on%20Denis%20Poisson">Poisson</a> in 1824, with Cauchy only becoming associated with it during an academic controversy in 1853. As such, the name of the distribution is a case of <a href="Stigler%27s%20law%20of%20eponymy">Stigler's Law of Eponymy</a>. Poisson noted that if the mean of observations following such a distribution were taken, the mean error did not converge to any finite number. As such, <a href="Pierre-Simon%20Laplace">Laplace</a>'s use of the <a href="central%20limit%20theorem">central limit theorem</a> with such distribution was inappropriate, as it assumed a finite mean and variance. Despite this, Poisson did not regard the issue as important, in contrast to <a href="Ir%C3%A9n%C3%A9e-Jules%20Bienaym%C3%A9">Bienaymé</a>, who was to engage Cauchy in a long dispute over the matter.

Properties.
The Cauchy distribution is an example of a distribution which has no <a href="mean">mean</a>, <a href="variance">variance</a> or higher <a href="moment%20%28mathematics%29">moments</a> defined. Its <a href="mode%20%28statistics%29">mode</a> and <a href="median">median</a> are well defined and are both equal to formula_4.

It is also an example of a more generalized version of the central limit theorem that is characteristic of all <a href="stable%20distribution">stable distribution</a>s, of which the Cauchy distribution is a special case.
The Cauchy distribution is an <a href="infinitely%20divisible%20probability%20distribution">infinitely divisible probability distribution</a>. It is also a strictly <a href="stability%20%28probability%29">stable</a> distribution.
The standard Cauchy distribution coincides with the <a href="Student%27s%20t-distribution">Student's "t"-distribution</a> with one degree of freedom.
Like all stable distributions, the <a href="location-scale%20family">location-scale family</a> to which the Cauchy distribution belongs is closed under <a href="linear%20transformations">linear transformations</a> with <a href="real%20number">real</a> coefficients. In addition, the Cauchy distribution is closed under <a href="M%C3%B6bius%20transformation">linear fractional transformations</a> with real coefficients. In this connection, see also <a href="McCullagh%27s%20parametrization%20of%20the%20Cauchy%20distributions">McCullagh's parametrization of the Cauchy distributions</a>.

Observe that the characteristic function is not <a href="Differentiable%20function">differentiable</a> at the origin: this corresponds to the fact that the Cauchy distribution does not have well-defined moments higher than the zeroth moment.

Higher moments.
The Cauchy distribution does not have finite moments of any order. Some of the higher <a href="raw%20moment">raw moment</a>s do exist and have a value of infinity, for example, the raw second moment:
By re-arranging the formula, one can see that the second moment is essentially the infinite integral of a constant (here 1). Higher even-powered raw moments will also evaluate to infinity. Odd-powered raw moments, however, are undefined, which is distinctly different from existing with the value of infinity. The odd-powered raw moments are undefined because their values are essentially equivalent to formula_66 since the two halves of the integral both diverge and have opposite signs. The first raw moment is the mean, which, being odd, does not exist. (See also the discussion above about this.) This in turn means that all of the <a href="central%20moment">central moment</a>s and <a href="standardized%20moment">standardized moment</a>s are undefined since they are all based on the mean. The variance—which is the second central moment—is likewise non-existent (despite the fact that the raw second moment exists with the value infinity).
The results for higher moments follow from <a href="H%C3%B6lder%27s%20inequality">Hölder's inequality</a>, which implies that higher moments (or halves of moments) diverge if lower ones do.
Moments of truncated distributions.
Consider the <a href="truncated%20distribution">truncated distribution</a> defined by restricting the standard Cauchy distribution to the interval . Such a truncated distribution has all moments (and the central limit theorem applies for <a href="i.i.d.">i.i.d.</a> observations from it); yet for almost all practical purposes it behaves like a Cauchy distribution.
Estimation of parameters.
Because the parameters of the Cauchy distribution do not correspond to a mean and variance, attempting to estimate the parameters of the Cauchy distribution by using a sample mean and a sample variance will not succeed. For example, if an i.i.d. sample of size "n" is taken from a Cauchy distribution, one may calculate the sample mean as:
Although the sample values formula_68 will be concentrated about the central value formula_4, the sample mean will become increasingly variable as more observations are taken, because of the increased probability of encountering sample points with a large absolute value. In fact, the distribution of the sample mean will be equal to the distribution of the observations themselves; i.e., the sample mean of a large sample is no better (or worse) an estimator of formula_4 than any single observation from the sample. Similarly, calculating the sample variance will result in values that grow larger as more observations are taken.
Therefore, more robust means of estimating the central value formula_4 and the scaling parameter formula_5 are needed. One simple method is to take the median value of the sample as an estimator of formula_4 and half the sample <a href="interquartile%20range">interquartile range</a> as an estimator of formula_5. Other, more precise and robust methods have been developed For example, the <a href="truncated%20mean">truncated mean</a> of the middle 24% of the sample <a href="order%20statistics">order statistics</a> produces an estimate for formula_4 that is more efficient than using either the sample median or the full sample mean. However, because of the <a href="fat%20tails">fat tails</a> of the Cauchy distribution, the efficiency of the estimator decreases if more than 24% of the sample is used.
<a href="Maximum%20likelihood">Maximum likelihood</a> can also be used to estimate the parameters formula_4 and formula_5. However, this tends to be complicated by the fact that this requires finding the roots of a high degree polynomial, and there can be multiple roots that represent local maxima. Also, while the maximum likelihood estimator is asymptotically efficient, it is relatively inefficient for small samples. Relativistic Breit–Wigner distribution.
In <a href="nuclear%20physics">nuclear</a> and <a href="particle%20physics">particle physics</a>, the energy profile of a <a href="resonance">resonance</a> is described by the <a href="relativistic%20Breit%E2%80%93Wigner%20distribution">relativistic Breit–Wigner distribution</a>, while the Cauchy distribution is the (non-relativistic) Breit–Wigner distribution.
